regimens.name: Neonatal protocol
regimens.dosing: Weight-based: 5 mg/kg OD (≥2.5 kg) or 3 mg/kg OD (<2.5 kg)
regimens.source: Guideline for Neonatal Care, Tz 2019; STG Children & Adolescents, Tanzania 2017
regimens.warning: ⚠️ ALWAYS in combination with other antibiotics (see Neonatal Care Guidelines for specific combinations)
regimens.notes: Includes: Neonatal sepsis, meningitis, pneumonia, omphalitis, bacterial skin infection, HIE, NEC, premature infants <34 weeks prophylaxis. Commonly combined with Ampicillin or Ampiclox.

regimens.name: Monotherapy regimen
regimens.duration: Until fever subsides, then switch to oral antibiotics
regimens.source: WHO Pocket Book of Hospital Care for Children 2013
regimens.notes: For young infants <2 months with uncomplicated UTI. Monitor for signs of systemic infection.

regimens.name: Combination regimen
regimens.source: STG and NEMLIT, Tanzania 2021; WHO Pocket Book 2013
regimens.notes: For urosepsis or complicated UTI. Complete 10 days total treatment.

regimens.name: Standard regimen
regimens.source: STG Children & Adolescents, Tanzania 2017; WHO Pocket Book 2013; STG and NEMLIT Tz 2021
regimens.notes: Includes: Severe pneumonia, pleural effusion/empyema, lung abscess, Klebsiella pneumonia. For pleural effusion/empyema: continue cloxacillin orally for total 3 weeks after improvement.

regimens.name: Standard regimen
regimens.source: STG Children & Adolescents, Tanzania 2017; STG and NEMLIT, Tanzania 2021
regimens.notes: Includes: Meningitis (infants <3 months), septicaemia, septic shock, puerperal sepsis. Add Cloxacillin if staphylococcal infection suspected (e.g., impetigo, abscess present).

indications.condition: Infective Endocarditis (STG Children & Adolescents Tz 2017, STG and NEMLIT Tz 2021)

regimens.name: Treatment protocol
regimens.source: STG Children & Adolescents, Tanzania 2017; STG and NEMLIT, Tanzania 2021
regimens.warning: ⚠️ In combination with Benzyl Penicillin/Ampicillin/Cloxacillin (see guidelines for specific regimens)
regimens.notes: Duration: 2 weeks for standard protocol, 6 weeks for enterococcal/resistant streptococcal/staphylococcal endocarditis. Monitor serum gentamicin levels every 3-4 days.

regimens.name: Prophylaxis (GI/GU procedures)
regimens.warning: ⚠️ In combination with Ampicillin/Amoxicillin IV 50 mg/kg
regimens.notes: For patients with CHD undergoing dental, gastrointestinal, or genitourinary procedures.

regimens.name: Standard regimen
regimens.source: STG Children & Adolescents, Tanzania 2017; WHO Pocket Book 2013; STG and NEMLIT Tz 2021
regimens.notes: Includes: Appendicitis, bowel obstruction, intussusception, abdominal wall defects (gastroschisis/omphalocele), incarcerated hernia. For bowel obstruction/abdominal wall defects: Metronidazole loading dose 15 mg/kg, then 7.5 mg/kg q12h.

regimens.name: Standard regimen
regimens.source: STG Children & Adolescents, Tanzania 2017; WHO Pocket Book 2013; STG and NEMLIT Tz 2021
regimens.notes: Includes: Open fractures, osteomyelitis, septic arthritis, burns with septicaemia, necrotizing fasciitis, open wounds. Add Metronidazole if bowel flora suspected.

regimens.name: Standard regimen
regimens.source: STG Children & Adolescents, Tanzania 2017; STG and NEMLIT, Tanzania 2021
regimens.notes: Includes: Orbital cellulitis (with ceftriaxone/cloxacillin), dental abscess if PCN allergy (with clindamycin), PID (with clindamycin), sequestration syndromes in SCA (with ampicillin). Refer to specific guidelines for combination protocols.

injection.notes: As sulfate - AVOID undiluted use, dilute before administration

importantNotes: ⚠️ OTOTOXIC and NEPHROTOXIC - ALWAYS monitor renal function and hearing
Prefer diluted solutions - AVOID undiluted 40 mg/ml gentamicin
Risk for adverse effects when given with theophylline
Maximum adult dose for reference: 120 mg once daily (or 80-160 mg depending on indication)
ALWAYS given in combination except for uncomplicated UTI in infants <2 months

monitoring.title: ⚠️ THERAPEUTIC DRUG MONITORING
requirements: Monitor serum gentamicin levels every 3-4 days for prolonged treatment (>5-7 days)
Peak concentration (1-hour post-dose): should NOT exceed 10 mg/L
Trough concentration (pre-dose, 2-hour before next dose): should be <2 mg/L
Adjust dose in renal failure based on creatinine clearance (CrCl)
toxicity: Ototoxicity: Monitor hearing, especially in prolonged treatment
Nephrotoxicity: Monitor serum creatinine and urine output
Increased risk with concurrent use of other ototoxic/nephrotoxic drugs
drugInteractions: Neuromuscular blocking agents: Prolonged neuromuscular blockade

administrationGuidance.title: Administration Guidelines
administrationGuidance.dilution: Avoid using undiluted 40 mg/ml solution. Dilute in normal saline or 5% dextrose before IV administration
administrationGuidance.routes: IV (preferred for severe infections) or IM
administrationGuidance.compatibility: Check compatibility before mixing with other antibiotics in same IV line
